figure_1.title: Fig 1. The journal eLife’s interface for indicating contributions when submitting a manuscript, available online at https://elifesciences.org/inside-elife/f39cfcf5/enabling-the-contributor-roles-taxonomy-for-author-contributions.

figure_2.title: Fig 2. The PLOS journals’ interface for indicating contributions when submitting a manuscript.
figure_2.caption: It appears when one is asked to enter information about each author.

figure_3.title: Fig 3. Partial screenshot of the spreadsheet template (http://bit.ly/tenzingTemplate).

figure_4.title: Fig 4. Screenshot of the tenzing window that provides a report of author contributions.

figure_5.title: Fig 5. A screenshot of a portion of the JATS-XML output provided by tenzing.

figure_6.title: Fig 6. A screenshot of the tenzing app.
figure_6.caption: The bottom portion of both sides describes the four outputs that tenzing provides.

figure_7.title: Fig 7. A screenshot of the author list and affiliation output screen.

claims.sentence: For example, in the submission interface of eLife, authors encounter an array of checkboxes to indicate which category each author contributed to (Fig 1).

Open in a new tabPLOS journals provide a similar facility (Fig 2), as do over 1200 Elsevier journals (https://www.elsevier.com/about/press-releases/corporate/elsevier-expands-credit-approach-to-authorship).
For a given research project, researchers make a copy of the template and then, in the rows, enter the names of their collaborators (Fig 3).
For CRediT, tenzing outputs a brief report in the form of a list indicating which contributor did what (Fig 4).

Open in a new tabThe publishing platforms used by dozens of publishers can include CRediT metadata in JATS-XML-format in the journal article webpages (see http://credit.niso.org/implementing-credit/). tenzing can generate this JATS-XML information itself for users to download (Fig 5).
The current user interface for tenzing is shown in Fig 6, although its design is likely to evolve–a usability study is presently underway.

Open in a new tab
The bottom portion of both sides describes the four outputs that tenzing provides.An additional output provided by tenzing is unrelated to CRediT: a list of the authors’ names, with annotations indicating the institutions they are affiliated with, formatted to be suitable to paste into the title page of a manuscript file (Fig 7).

Figure 2 (as for eLife)
- Instead of links to external blogs, I recommend authors to provide tables describing different features of CRediT e.g. limitations and applicability.

Figure 2 (as for eLife)
Done.
- Instead of links to external blogs, I recommend authors to provide tables describing different features of CRediT e.g. limitations and applicability.
For example, in the submission interface of eLife, authors encounter an array of checkboxes to indicate which category each author contributed to (Fig 1).

Open in a new tabPLOS journals provide a similar facility (Fig 2), as do over 1200 Elsevier journals (https://www.elsevier.com/about/press-releases/corporate/elsevier-expands-credit-approach-to-authorship).
For a given research project, researchers make a copy of the template and then, in the rows, enter the names of their collaborators (Fig 3).
For CRediT, tenzing outputs a brief report in the form of a list indicating which contributor did what (Fig 4).

Open in a new tabThe publishing platforms used by dozens of publishers can include CRediT metadata in JATS-XML-format in the journal article webpages (see http://credit.niso.org/implementing-credit/). tenzing can generate this JATS-XML information itself for users to download (Fig 5).
The current user interface for tenzing is shown in Fig 6, although its design is likely to evolve–a usability study is presently underway.

Open in a new tab
The bottom portion of both sides describes the four outputs that tenzing provides.An additional output provided by tenzing is unrelated to CRediT: a list of the authors’ names, with annotations indicating the institutions they are affiliated with, formatted to be suitable to paste into the title page of a manuscript file (Fig 7).

- Instead of links to external blogs, I recommend authors to provide tables describing different features of CRediT e.g. limitations and applicability.

For example, in the submission interface of eLife, authors encounter an array of checkboxes to indicate which category each author contributed to (Fig 1).

Open in a new tabPLOS journals provide a similar facility (Fig 2), as do over 1200 Elsevier journals (https://www.elsevier.com/about/press-releases/corporate/elsevier-expands-credit-approach-to-authorship).
For example, in the submission interface of eLife, authors encounter an array of checkboxes to indicate which category each author contributed to (Fig 1).
PLOS journals provide a similar facility (Fig 2), as do over 1200 Elsevier journals (https://www.elsevier.com/about/press-releases/corporate/elsevier-expands-credit-approach-to-authorship).
For a given research project, researchers make a copy of the template and then, in the rows, enter the names of their collaborators (Fig 3).
For CRediT, tenzing outputs a brief report in the form of a list indicating which contributor did what (Fig 4).

Open in a new tabThe publishing platforms used by dozens of publishers can include CRediT metadata in JATS-XML-format in the journal article webpages (see http://credit.niso.org/implementing-credit/). tenzing can generate this JATS-XML information itself for users to download (Fig 5).
The current user interface for tenzing is shown in Fig 6, although its design is likely to evolve–a usability study is presently underway.

Open in a new tab
The bottom portion of both sides describes the four outputs that tenzing provides.An additional output provided by tenzing is unrelated to CRediT: a list of the authors’ names, with annotations indicating the institutions they are affiliated with, formatted to be suitable to paste into the title page of a manuscript file (Fig 7).
For a given research project, researchers make a copy of the template and then, in the rows, enter the names of their collaborators (Fig 3).
For CRediT, tenzing outputs a brief report in the form of a list indicating which contributor did what (Fig 4).

The publishing platforms used by dozens of publishers can include CRediT metadata in JATS-XML-format in the journal article webpages (see http://credit.niso.org/implementing-credit/). tenzing can generate this JATS-XML information itself for users to download (Fig 5).
The current user interface for tenzing is shown in Fig 6, although its design is likely to evolve–a usability study is presently underway.

An additional output provided by tenzing is unrelated to CRediT: a list of the authors’ names, with annotations indicating the institutions they are affiliated with, formatted to be suitable to paste into the title page of a manuscript file (Fig 7).
